title: Bhrikutimandap Land Lease Corruption Case
description:
The Bhrikutimandap Land Lease case, also known as the Fun Park Corruption Case, involves significant irregularities in the leasing of 60 ropani of public land belonging to the Social Welfare Council (SWC) in a prime area of Kathmandu. The land was leased to operate a fun park.

In September 2012, a decision led by the then Minister for Women, Children and Social Welfare and SWC Chairperson, Badri Prasad Neupane, awarded a 15-year lease contract for the land to Kathmandu Fun Park. The Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA) investigated the matter following complaints and uncovered major procedural and financial misconduct.

The key findings of the CIAA investigation were:

  • Procedural Violations: The contract was awarded directly without a competitive public tender process, which is a mandatory requirement under Nepal's public procurement laws for managing state assets.
  • Gross Undervaluation: The land was leased for a monthly rent of NPR 555,000, amounting to approximately NPR 9,250 per ropani. The CIAA established that this rate was drastically below the market value, citing a nearby plot that was leased for NPR 78,571 per ropani, causing a substantial financial loss to the state.

On February 4, 2019, the CIAA filed a corruption case at the Special Court against 14 individuals, including former Minister Neupane, SWC officials, and the park operators. The CIAA claimed a total loss of NPR 315,200,000 to the state exchequer.

On February 28, 2023, the Special Court delivered its verdict, convicting nine of the accused. Badri Prasad Neupane was identified as the main perpetrator, while Nepali Congress lawmaker Tek Bahadur Gurung, an operator of the fun park, was convicted as an accomplice. The court acquitted five others. Sentences, including prison terms and hefty fines, were pronounced on March 9, 2023.
unverified_info: There are some minor discrepancies across various news reports regarding the exact fine amounts for some individuals. For instance, one source reports that Rabindra Gurung was ordered to pay over NPR 2.43 crore, while another suggests the amount was NPR 1.21 crore in fine and the same in restitution. The primary amounts have been recorded in the main case file based on the most consistent reporting.
key_allegations: Awarding a land lease contract without a public procurement/tender process.
Leasing public land at a significantly undervalued rate, causing financial loss to the state.
Abuse of authority by public officials for personal and collective gain.
related_entities: Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA)
Government of Nepal, Ministry of Women, Children and Social Welfare

timeline.title: Land Lease Contract Awarded
timeline.description: The Social Welfare Council, chaired by Minister Badri Neupane, awarded a 15-year contract to Rabindra Gurung to operate a fun park on 60 ropani of land in Bhrikutimandap without a competitive bidding process.

timeline.title: CIAA Files Corruption Case
timeline.description: The CIAA filed a corruption case at the Special Court against 14 individuals, including former Minister Badri Prasad Neupane and lawmaker Tek Bahadur Gurung, alleging a loss of NPR 315.2 million.

timeline.title: MP Tek Bahadur Gurung Suspended
timeline.description: The Federal Parliament Secretariat suspended Tek Bahadur Gurung from his position as a Member of Parliament due to the sub judice corruption case against him.

timeline.title: Special Court Convicts Nine Individuals
timeline.description: The Special Court, in a bench of Shree Kanta Paudel, Shaligram Koirala, and Balbhadra Bastola, convicted nine out of the fourteen accused, including Badri Prasad Neupane and Tek Bahadur Gurung. Five were acquitted.

timeline.title: Sentences Pronounced
timeline.description: The Special Court announced the sentences for the nine convicts. Badri Prasad Neupane was sentenced to 9 years and 6 months in prison and fined, while Tek Bahadur Gurung was fined but received no jail time.

timeline.title: Supreme Court Revokes MP's Suspension
timeline.description: The Supreme Court revoked the suspension of MP Tek Bahadur Gurung, ruling that a conviction without a jail sentence did not warrant suspension under the Prevention of Corruption Act.

sources.description: My Republica report from March 9, 2023, outlining the specific sentences, including prison terms and fines, handed down by the Special Court to the nine individuals convicted in the case.

sources.description: The Kathmandu Post report from March 29, 2024, on the Supreme Court's decision to overturn the suspension of MP Tek Bahadur Gurung, allowing him to resume his parliamentary duties.
